page.title: 01The Pennines - Eastern Slope
page.content: The Grouse Moors to the E of Midderdale in N Yorkshire slope down & change to marginal sheep & cattle grazing land in the direction of the York Plain. The block typifies this gradual change in terrain. Several typical Yorkshire stone farms can be seen. Dry stone walls & hedgerows are in abundance. Fields are small. Gills (small steep-sided water course ravines) are lined with both deciduous & coniferous woodland. Sheep flocks & cattle are frequently seen. Grouse can be seen & heard inhabiting the moors & margins. Grouse shooting butts exist. There is currently no land under cultivation (arable). Roads, though narrow in places, are well maintained & are all of tar macadam surface. Milk is collected by road tanker. Overhead electricity cables carry supplies to the farms.
